question: Just looking around.
answer: Comrades, why should we lie to each other? It's wonderful.

question: Let's be honest. Have we anything like it in Russia? Can you imagine what the beds would be in a hotel like that?
answer: They tell me when you ring once the valet comes in; when you ring twice you get the waiter; and do you know what happens when you ring three times? A maid comes in -- a French maid.

question: Monsieur.
answer: I am Comrade Buljanoff.

question: Monsieur.
answer: May I ask how much your rooms are?

question: Well, gentlemen, I'm afraid our rates are rather high.
answer: Why should you be afraid?

question: I might be able to accommodate you. Is there some more luggage?
answer: Oh, yes, but have you a safe here big enough to hold this?

question: I'm afraid we have no boxes of that size in our vault, but there is one suite with a private safe...
answer: That's even better.

question: Royal Suite! Just a minute. Now Comrades, I warn you... if it gets out in Moscow that we stay in the Royal Suite we will get into terrible trouble.
answer: We'll just say we had to take it on account of the safe. That's a perfect excuse. There was no other safe big enough.

question: Of course, we could take out the pieces and distribute them in three or four boxes in the vault and take a small room. That's an idea, isn't it?
answer: Yes, it's an idea, but who says we have to have an idea?

question: That's all right.
answer: Hello, Leon!

question: Good morning, Swana.
answer: It's really a wretched morning... wretched. I can't get myself right. I wanted to look mellow and I look brittle. My face doesn't compose well... all highlights... how can I dim myself down, Leon? Suggest something. I am so bored with this face. I wish I had someone else's face. Whose face would you have if you had your choice? Oh, well, I guess one gets the face one deserves.

question: Your conversation has one marvelous advantage, Swana. However many questions you ask you never expect an answer.
answer: Don't you find that restful?... Why didn't you come last night?

question: Darling, I was busy looking out for your interests.
answer: Did you win?

question: We can forget horse racing, roulette, the stock market... our worries are over! You remember that platinum watch with the diamond numbers? You will be in a position to give it to me.
answer: Oh, Leon, you are so good to me.

question: We can be rich if you say the word. I had dinner with the Guizots last night.
answer: Those newspaper people?

question: You'd be surprised how many nice people dine with the Guizots.
answer: What a gruesome proof of the power of the press!

question: Now listen, Swana... I sold Monsieur Guizot the idea of publishing your memoirs in the Gazette Parisienne. "The Life and Loves of the Grand Duchess Swana of Russia"!
answer: Oh, Leon!

question: Sweetheart, we won't have to bother about our future if you are willing to raffle off your past!
answer: Was it for this that I refused to endorse Dr. Bertrand's Mouthwash? I could have made a little fortune by saying that the Vincent Vacuum Cleaner was the only vacuum cleaner ever used by the Romanoffs... and now you want them to smear my life's secrets over the front page of a tabloid?

question: I understand how you feel, but there is a limit to everything, particularly pride and dignity. They are willing to pay any price! They have a circulation of two million!
answer: Imagine two million clerks and shop girls peeking into my life for a sou! Think of my lovely life being wrapped around cheese and blood sausages! I can see a big grease spot in the midst of my most intimate moments!

question: Well, I am the last person to persuade you, but don't do it blindly... if this is your decision, you must be prepared to face the consequences... I will have to go to work.
answer: My little Volga boatman! Stop threatening! I don't deserve this. Are you my little Volga boatman?

question: Now, Swana...
answer: First tell me, are you my little Volga boatman?

question: Yes, I'm your little Volga boatman.
answer: Well... two million readers... I know exactly what they want. Chapter One

question: I've got one chapter Guizot thinks is terrific. "Caviar and Blood." Swana escapes over the ice!
answer: A couple of bloodhounds and we have Uncle Tom's Cabin.

question: Darling, this would be wonderful! Just once... weren't you attacked by a Bolshevik?
answer: Was I? No... not by a Bolshevik!

question: Too bad! Brings our price down ten thousand francs!
answer: Come in.

question: Your Highness.
answer: How do you do, my friend.

question: Your Highness, forgive this intrusion, but...
answer: What is it, Rakonin? Did you lose your job?

question: No, madame, something of the utmost importance... it concerns your jewels.
answer: My jewels?!

question: I remember one birthday of His Majesty, our beloved Czar... I had the honor of being on guard at the summer palace... I still see you bending before His Majesty... You wore your diadem and a necklace... your face seemed to be lighted by the jewels.
answer: Why do you bring this up after so many years?

question: They are here!... Your jewels!... Here in Paris!
answer: Alexis! Do you know what you are saying?

question: Thank you so much, my friend. I will get in touch with you. This is the Duchess Swana... I want to speak to Monsieur Cornillon... it's very important... please get him right away... Hello, Monsieur Cornillon? The most incredible thing has happened! My jewels are here in Paris! Three Bolshevik swine are trying to sell them! Yes... yes... we must act immediately!... Call the police... Have them arrested!... Well, then, get an injunction!... But do something, Monsieur Cornillon! ...But they are my jewels! There must be some way of getting them back!
answer: What does he say?

question: Shhh! ...But how can there be a question?... Are you my lawyer or theirs?... All right, I'll let you know!
answer: What did he say?

question: It looks pretty hopeless... there may be a chance... that's all... The French Government has recognized Soviet Russia and he doubts that they will risk a war for my poor sake. He might be able to make up some kind of a case but it would cost money, money, money!... That's all they are interested in -- those lawyers!
answer: Darling, calm down. Why do you need a lawyer? Haven't you your little Volga boatman?

question: We don't want to be disturbed.
answer: My name is Count d'Algout. I telephoned.

question: If you want to see us you must come later.
answer: I just want a word with Monsieur Mercier.

question: But you can't...
answer: Monsieur Mercier. May I introduce myself? I am Count Leon d'Algout. I think I had the pleasure of meeting you in your beautiful shop. I was admiring a platinum watch with diamond numbers.

question: Don't look so gloomy, gentlemen. All is not lost. You may have a chance.
answer: We may have a chance.

question: Yes... a very slim one. I want to be fair. I don't deny that you might make out some kind of a case.
answer: We haven't anything to discuss with you. We'll talk to a lawyer!

question: In any case, gentlemen, a charming, beautiful, exquisite woman. I warn you, if this case comes to trial it will be before a French court, and when the Duchess takes the stand...
answer: All right, go ahead, get her on the witness stand! What can she say?

question: But how will she look? The fashions this spring are very becoming to her. Gentlemen, the judge will be French, the jury will be French, everybody in that courtroom will be French. Have you ever seen a French court when a beautiful woman sits on the witness stand and lifts her skirt a little? You sit down and pull up your pants and where will it get you?
answer: I suppose you expect us to hand over the jewels?

question: Then let's say at nine.
answer: Black tie or white tie?

question: Oh, let's make it white.
answer: Certainly!

question: Nice people.
answer: Yes, Leon... What is it, Leon?... You can't hurry such things... You must give Moscow a little time... There's nothing we can do about it... why don't you drop in later?... Au revoir...

question: Misha! Misha!
answer: What is it?

question: I am looking for Michael Simonovitch Iranoff.
answer: I am Michael Simonovitch Iranoff.

question: I am Nina Ivanovna Yakushova, Envoy Extraordinary, acting under direct orders of Comrade Commissar Razinin. Present me to your colleagues.
answer: Comrade Buljanoff...

question: Comrade.
answer: Comrade Kopalski...

question: Comrade.
answer: What a charming idea for Moscow to surprise us with a lady comrade.

question: What do you want? Why?
answer: He is a porter. He wants to carry them.

question: Why?... Why should you carry other people's bags? That's no business... that's a social injustice.
answer: Allow me, Comrade.

question: Which part of the room is mine?
answer: You see... it is a little different here. They don't rent rooms in pieces. We had to take the whole suite.

question: How much does this cost?
answer: Two thousand francs.

question: A week?
answer: A day.

question: Do you know how much a cow costs, Comrade Iranoff?
answer: A cow?

question: I will not repeat your mistake. I will have no dealings with the Grand Duchess nor her representative. Comrade Buljanoff...
answer: Yes, Comrade?

question: Do you spell Buljanoff with one or two f's?
answer: With two f's, if you please.

question: Will you send me some cigarettes, please? Comrades, I am not in a position to pass final judgment but at best you have been careless in your duty to the State. You were entrusted with more than a mere sale of jewelry. Why are we peddling our precious possessions to the world at this time? Our next year's crop is in danger and you know it. Unless we can get foreign currency to buy tractors there will not be enough bread for our people. And you three comrades...
answer: We did it with the best intentions...

question: We cannot feed the Russian people on your intentions. Fifty per cent to a so-called Duchess!... Half of every loaf of bread to our enemy! Comrade Kopalski, go at once to our Embassy and get the address of the best lawyer in Paris.
answer: Yes, Comrade.

question: You, Comrade Iranoff, go to the Public Library and get me the section of the Civil Code on property.
answer: Is there anything I can do, Comrade?

question: You might get me an accurate map of Paris. I want to use my spare time to inspect the public utilities and make a study of all outstanding technical achievements in the city.
answer: Yes, Comrade.

question: Come in. Comrades, you seem to have been smoking a lot. Good evening. She exits out the door. You, please.
answer: Me?

question: Yes. Could you give me some information?
answer: Gladly.

question: How long do we have to wait here?
answer: Well -- until the policeman whistles again.

question: At what intervals does he whistle?
answer: What?

question: How many minutes between the first and second whistle?
answer: That's funny. It's interesting. I never gave it a thought before.

question: Have you never been caught in a similar situation?
answer: Have I? Do you know when I come to think about it it's staggering. If I add it all up I must have spent years waiting for signals. Imagine! An important part of my life wasted between whistles.

question: In other words you don't know.
answer: No.

question: Thank you.
answer: You're welcome. Can I help you?

question: You might hold this for me.
answer: Love to.

question: Correct me if I am wrong... We are facing north, aren't we?
answer: Facing north... I'd hate to commit myself without my compass... Pardon me... are you an explorer?

question: No... I am looking for the Eiffel Tower.
answer: Is that thing lost again?... Listen... if you are interested in a view...

question: I am interested in the Eiffel Tower from a technical standpoint.
answer: Technical... I couldn't help you from that angle. You see, a real Parisian only goes to the top of the tower in moments of despair to jump off.

question: How long does it take a man to land?
answer: Now, isn't that too bad! The last time I jumped I forgot to clock it! Let me see... Eiffel Tower... Your finger, please.

question: Why do you need my finger?
answer: Bad manners to point with your own... Here... the Eiffel Tower.

question: And where are we?
answer: Here... here we are... here you are and here I am... feel it?

question: I am interested only in the shortest distance between these two points. Must you flirt?
answer: I don't have to but I find it natural.

question: Suppress it.
answer: I'll try.

question: For my own information would you call your approach toward me typical of the local morale?
answer: Madame, it is that kind of approach which has made Paris what it is.

question: You are very sure of yourself, aren't you?
answer: Nothing has occurred recently to shake my confidence.

question: I have heard of the arrogant male in capitalistic society. It is having a superior earning power that makes you like that.
answer: A Russian! I love Russians! Comrade... I have been fascinated by your Five- Year Plan for the past fifteen years!

question: Your type will soon be extinct. Please... can you tell me the exact width of the foundation on which the piers are resting?... and the depth? I am not afraid... I want to know...
answer: The foundation is one hundred and forty-one yards square... I hope you'll forgive me but I thought you'd...

question: Go ahead.
answer: Four massive piers of masonry are sunk to a depth of forty-six feet on the side of the Seine, and twenty- nine and one-half feet on the other side. The girders of interlaced iron- work which stay the structure have an inclination of fifty-four degrees...

question: That's a strange angle.
answer: Yes, very strange. Ascending to the tower is a staircase consisting of eight hundred and twenty- nine steps... ...and an additional two hundred and fifty-four steps to the very top... There is an elevator included in the price of admission!

question: You gave me some very valuable information. Thank you.
answer: And thank you for getting me up here. I've never seen this before. Beautiful, isn't it?

question: Yes, it is.
answer: I'm glad I saw it before becoming extinct.

question: Do not misunderstand me. I do not hold your frivolity against you. As basic material you might not be bad, but you are the unfortunate product of a doomed culture. I feel sorry for you.
answer: You must admit that this doomed old civilization sparkles... It glitters!

question: I do not deny its beauty, but it is a waste of electricity.
answer: What a city! There are the Grands Boulevards... blasted out of the heart of the old streets. The Arc de Triomphe... made to greet Napoleon's army. The Opera! And Montmartre... Montparnasse... La Bohme... and now I'll show you the greatest attraction! It will cost me a franc but it is worth it. The most wonderful spot in all Paris -- unique! Here, look.... What do you see?

question: I see a house that looks like any other house. What's remarkable about it?
answer: It's not the structure but the spirit which dwells within. There are three rooms and a kitchenette dedicated to hospitality.

question: So that is your house?
answer: Well, let's say I live in it. Such a pleasant place... all kinds of comfort, easy to reach, close to street car, bus, and subway...

question: Does that mean that you want me to go there?
answer: Please don't misunderstand me...

question: Then you don't want me to go there.
answer: Now I didn't say that either... naturally nothing would please me more.

question: Then why don't we go? You might be an interesting subject of study.
answer: I will do my best.

question: Is this what you call the "butler"?
answer: Yes.

question: Good evening, comrade. This man is horribly old. You should not make him work.
answer: He takes good care of that.

question: He looks sad. Do you whip him?
answer: No, though the mere thought makes my mouth water.

question: Go to bed. Well, may I offer you a drink, or how about something to eat?
answer: Thank you. I've had all the calories necessary for today. What do we do now?

question: We take off our hat and coat. We sit down -- we make ourselves comfortable. We adjust ourselves to the prospect of a most enjoyable evening. We look at each other. We smile. Well... we don't smile. How about some music?
answer: Is that customary?

question: It helps. It has ever since King David wooed Bathsheba with the harp. As I am not so fortunate as to have my harp at hand, I shall turn on the radio.
answer: I should say this room is eighteen by twenty-five.

question: Not too big and not too small. What I'd call the typical room of an average man. Or shall we say a little above average. Now if there are any special aspects you wish to study I have nothing to conceal. Just look around. That's my desk. Those are my books, and here am I. Where shall we begin?
answer: I will start with you.

question: That's great. I'm thirty-five years old. Just over six feet tall. I weigh a hundred and eighty-two pounds stripped.
answer: And what is your profession?

question: Keeping my body fit, keeping my mind alert, keeping my landlord appeased. That's a full-time job.
answer: And what do you do for mankind?

question: For mankind not a thing -- for womankind the record is not quite so bleak.
answer: You are something we do not have in Russia.

question: Thank you. Thank you.
answer: That is why I believe in the future of my country.

question: I begin to believe in it myself since I've met you. I still don't know what to make of it. It confuses me, it frightens me a little, but it fascinates me, Ninotchka.
answer: You pronounce it incorrectly. Ni- notchka.

question: Ni-notchka.
answer: That is correct.

question: Ninotchka, do you like me just a little bit?
answer: Your general appearance is not distasteful.

question: Thank you.
answer: Look at me. The whites of your eyes are clear. Your cornea is excellent.

question: Your cornea is terrific. Tell me -- you're so expert on things -- can it be that I'm falling in love with you?
answer: You are bringing in wrong values. Love is a romantic designation for a most ordinary biological, or shall we say chemical, process. A lot of nonsense is talked and written about it.

question: Oh, I see. What do you use instead?
answer: I acknowledge the existence of a natural impulse common to all.

question: What can I possibly do to encourage such an impulse in you?
answer: You don't have to do a thing. Chemically we are already quite sympathetic.

question: You're the most improbable creature I've ever met in my life, Ninotchka, Ninotchka...
answer: You repeat yourself.

question: I'd like to say it a thousand times.
answer: Don't do it, please.

question: I'm at a loss, Ninotchka. You must forgive me if I appear a little old- fashioned. After all, I'm just a poor bourgeois.
answer: It's never too late to change. I used to belong to the petty bourgeoisie myself. My father and mother wanted me to stay and work on the farm, but I preferred the bayonet.

question: The bayonet? Did you really?
answer: I was wounded before Warsaw.

question: Wounded? How?
answer: I was a sergeant in the Third Cavalry Brigade. Would you like to see my wound?

question: I'd love to. Tsk, tsk, tsk.
answer: A Polish lancer. I was sixteen.

question: Poor Ninotchka. Poor, poor Ninotchka.
answer: Don't pity me. Pity the Polish lancer. After all, I'm alive.

question: What kind of a girl are you, anyway?
answer: Just what you see. A tiny cog in the great wheel of evolution.

question: You're the most adorable cog I ever saw in my life. Ninotchka, Cogitska, let me confess something. Never did I dream I could feel like this toward a sergeant. Do you hear that?
answer: It's twelve o'clock.

question: It's midnight. One half of Paris is making love to the other half. Look at the clock. One hand has met the other hand. They kiss. Isn't that wonderful?
answer: That's the way a clock works. There's nothing wonderful about it. You merely feel you must put yourself in a romantic mood to add to your exhilaration.

question: I can't possibly think of a better reason.
answer: It's false sentimentality.

question: You analyze everything out of existence. You analyze me out of existence. I won't let you. Love is not so simple. Ninotchka, Ninotchka, why do doves bill and coo? Why do snails, coldest of all creatures, circle interminably around each other? Why do moths fly hundreds of miles to find their mates? Why do flowers open their petals? Oh, Ninotchka, Ninotchka, surely you feel some slight symptom of the divine passion... a general warmth in the palms of your hands... a strange heaviness in your limbs... a burning of the lips that is not thirst but a thousand times more tantalizing, more exalting, than thirst?
answer: You are very talkative.

question: Was that talkative?
answer: No, that was restful. Again. Thank you.

question: Oh, my barbaric Ninotchka. My impossible, unromantic, statistical... Glorious, analytical...
answer: The telephone is ringing.

question: Oh, let it ring.
answer: But one of your friends may be in need of you. You must answer.

question: Hello?... Yes... I'm sorry but I couldn't make it. I ran into a friend from the army... What?... The deal is off! Are you crazy, Buljanoff?... ...A special envoy arrived... What?... That sounds better. I'll be glad to see her any time she wants... Oh, she doesn't want to see me? What do you know about that? Why?... Well, I'll get in touch with her myself. What's her name?... ...What?... Yaku... How do you spell it?... Heavens! those Russian names! ...I... Oh, Y... Yakushova... Ninotch... All right. Thank you. Ninotchka...
answer: I must go.

question: Ninotchka, or shall I say Special Envoy Yakushova...
answer: Let's forget that we ever met.

question: I have a better suggestion. Let's forget that the telephone ever rang. I never heard that you are Yakushova... you are Ninotchka... my Ninotchka...
answer: I was sent here by my country to fight you.

question: All right, fight me, fight me as much as you want, but fight me tomorrow morning! There's nothing sweeter than sharing a secret with a bitter enemy.
answer: As a representative of Moscow...

question: Tonight let's not represent anybody but ourselves.
answer: It is out of the question. If you wish to approach me...

question: You know I want to...
answer: Then do it through my lawyer!

question: Ninotchka, you can't walk out like this... I'm crazy about you, and I thought I'd made an impression on you. You liked the white of my eye.
answer: I must go.

question: But, Ninotchka, I held you in my arms. You kissed me!
answer: I kissed the Polish lancer too... before he died.

question: That's all right. Leon! What in heaven's name...!
answer: Huh?

question: Is anything wrong? Are you ill?
answer: No.

question: Don't tell me the bed has lost its best friend.
answer: I just couldn't sleep. I got up and went back... and then got up again. These last few days... whew!

question: Not in your condition. Make it tepid, Gaston... tepid and tender. And lay out his gray suit. Afterwards I'll drive you through the Bois. Slowly... in Waltz time.
answer: A blue shirt, perhaps?

question: Blue? Let's offset his mood. Find a striped one, and brighten it with a great blaze of tie.
answer: Very well, Your Highness.

question: Now... here we have two very handsome soft-boiled eggs. Do you suppose hens mind what happens to their eggs? Probably not. They have such unfeeling eyes. We'll put in a great nugget of butter, plenty of pepper and salt... Darling, I haven't seen you for three livelong days... seventy-two hours!
answer: Oh, please, Swana! I don't know whether I'm standing on my head or my heels. Here you are blaming me for neglecting you when I'm trying to concentrate on another woman and can't get near her.

question: You haven't seen her yet?
answer: No, and believe me I've tried everything! I must have telephoned her a hundred times. I've sent her telegrams, I've sent her flowers... I asked her to dinner... I offered her seats for the Opera...

question: That proletarian! In the old days we'd have had her flogged.
answer: That wouldn't have done any good. Not with her. She's the most incredible creature I've ever seen.

question: You just told me you hadn't seen her.
answer: Well... er... I caught a glimpse of her when she walked through the lobby.

question: Imagine the carpets of a self- respecting Parisian hotel dirtied by the boots of a muzhik! What does she look like?
answer: You can't imagine.

question: That bad? Old or young?
answer: Timeless. When she comes into a room you'd think that the Bolsheviks had taken over Paris. She wears her cheap miserable blouse as though it were the latest model by Schiaparelli. What a woman! What a woman! There is a Russian snowstorm in each of her eyes.

question: You saw all that in one glimpse?
answer: Darling, if we're going to get anywhere someone has to keep his eyes open!

question: Now, darling, soak in your beautiful pine bath and let Gaston shave you. Gaston! Yes?
answer: We want to talk to Count d'Algout. My name is Kopalski.

question: Oh... you are the three gentlemen from Moscow?
answer: Yes.

question: Tsk, tsk, tsk.
answer: Where to, madame?

question: Can you recommend a restaurant?
answer: Well, there's Pruniers if you care for seafood. If you want to lunch in the Bois, there's...

question: Where do you eat?
answer: At Pre Mathieu's.

question: Where is that?
answer: It's just a place for workmen.

question: Where is it?
answer: Eight blocks down in the Rue de Poivrel.

question: Thank you. This will do. Raw carrots and beets.
answer: Why, hello! It certainly is a small world! Crayfish soup for me!

question: Bring me something simple. I never think about food. The future of the common people.
answer: Pardon me for addressing you but you insulted him, you know that. You hurt his feelings. It was just like telling a musician you don't like music. That good old man believes in food as you believe in Karl Marx. You can't go around hurting people, Comrade Yakushova, but maybe you can make it up to him. Do you know how? By eating everything with relish, by drinking everything with gusto, by having a good time for the first time in your natural life!

question: I don't like your following me.
answer: I didn't follow you.

question: Then how did you get here?
answer: I always eat here.

question: This is a place for workmen.
answer: But my dear child, I am most at home among working men. I hate the places where you circulate -- the Hotel Clarence... This is my natural element. After all, what are any of us? Workingmen! At least, those of us who are worth our salt. Hyah? Hyah! Hyah, fellows! They are all my friends. They're a swell bunch! Ah, my friend! I'm happy to see you again! Just an old man. His memory is getting weak.

question: What are you after?
answer: Must one always be after something?

question: Your tactics are useless. My name is neither Buljanoff, Iranoff, nor Kopalski.
answer: Oh, Ninotchka, who wants to talk business. If you win the suit, fine. If we win the suit, better. You do me an injustice. When we went to my apartment did I have the slightest idea that you had any connection with this deal?

question: But you have now, and I know now that you are a man who employs business methods which in Russia would be punished by death.
answer: Death! Death! Always so glum! What about life, Ninotchka! Do Russians never think of life? Of the moment in which we are living? The only moment we really have? Don't take it all so seriously, Ninotchka. Nothing is worth it. Please... relax... I beg you, Sergeant... smile!

question: What?
answer: Will you smile?

question: Why?
answer: Just smile.

question: At what?
answer: At anything. At the whole ludicrous spectacle of life. At people being pompous and taking themselves seriously and exaggerating their own importance. If you can't find anything else to laugh at you can laugh at you and me.

question: Why?
answer: Because we are an odd couple.

question: Then you should go back to your table.
answer: No, I can't leave you. I won't. Not yet. Not until I've made you laugh... at least once.

question: Ha! Ha! Now go back.
answer: That's not a laugh! I mean a laugh from the heart. Now let's see. I'm going to tell you a funny story. Just a moment... I've got it! Well, it seems there were a couple of Frenchmen who went to America...

question: On which boat?
answer: Well, er... let's drop it. I don't think you would care for that one.

question: Probably not.
answer: Do you like Scotch stories?

question: I have never heard one.
answer: Two Scotchmen met on the street... and I don't know the name of the street and it really doesn't matter. Well, anyway, one's name was McIntosh and the other's was McGillicuddy. McIntosh says to McGillicuddy, "Hello, Mr. McGillicuddy," and McGillicuddy says to McIntosh, "Hello, Mr. McIntosh," and then McIntosh says to McGillicuddy, "How is Mrs. McGillicuddy?" and then McGillicuddy says to McIntosh, "How is Mrs. McIntosh?"...

question: I wish they had never met.
answer: So do I. Now, here's a great one... Ha! Ha! Ha! Well, maybe it's not so good. Let's forget it! How's this? Two men are looking at the moon. One says to the other, "Is it true that a lot of people live on the moon?" "Yes, it is," says the other, "five hundred million." "Whew!" replies the first, "they must get pretty crowded when it's half moon!" Ha! Ha! Ha! I suppose you don't think that's funny?

question: No.
answer: It seemed funny to me when I first heard it. Maybe the trouble isn't with the joke. Maybe it's with you!

question: I don't think so.
answer: Maybe you haven't any sense of humor. Well, I'll give you one more chance! Now listen! When I heard this joke for the first time I laughed myself sick. Here goes! A man comes into a restaurant and sits down and says, "Waiter! Get me a cup of coffee without cream." After five minutes the waiter comes back and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we're all out of cream, can it be without milk?" Not funny, huh?

question: No.
answer: So you don't think that's funny? It is funny! Everyone else thinks so! Maybe you didn't get it. I'll tell you that joke again. A man comes into a restaurant. Did you get that?

question: Yes.
answer: He sits down at the table and says to the waiter... Did you get that too?

question: Yes.
answer: Well, so far it isn't funny, but wait. He says to the waiter, "Waiter! Bring me a cup of coffee." So the waiter comes back five minutes later and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we have no coffee."... Wait a minute... wait a minute... I'm all mixed up... A man comes in a restaurant, he sits down, he calls the waiter and he says, "Waiter! Get me a cup of coffee without cream," and five minutes later the waiter comes back and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we have no cream, can it be a glass of milk!" Ah! You have no sense of humor! That settles it! You have no sense of humor! None! No humor!! What's funny about this?

question: In addition to the arguments above enumerated for lifting this injunction, we wish to cite the decision of the High Court of Paris, rendered in the case of Princess Marishka against the Government of Montenegro on the fifth day of August, 1897. Comparing the facts in that case with our present set of facts we feel that the Treaty between the Republic of France and the U.S.S.R. should prevail over all...
answer: I'm sorry, gentlemen. The other day I heard such a funny story... It still makes me laugh. It is very funny. I am sorry. Oh yes... about this injunction...

question: The hearing is set for the twentieth of this month.
answer: That's two weeks from Thursday...

question: We did our utmost to have it set ahead.
answer: I know, gentlemen, but it is in the hands of the Court. We're helpless, aren't we?

question: Yes. It is unfortunate.
answer: Well, there's nothing we can do about it. Why get excited?

question: We'll leave these papers here for your further consideration. Au revoir, madame.
answer: Au revoir. Well, it means another two weeks in Paris.

question: No, not a thing. Would you like to go out?
answer: Thank you, Comrade.

question: Have you any money? Well, here are fifty francs.
answer: Thank you, Comrade, thank you.

question: Bring me forty-five back.
answer: Naturally, Comrade.

question: What time have you, Gaston?
answer: Eight forty-two, sir.

question: I guess it is eight forty-two.
answer: You seem to be a bit nervous, sir.

question: I am, Gaston.
answer: If you will forgive me, ever since you met that Bolshevik lady I've noticed a distinct change in you, sir.

question: Have you?
answer: Decidedly. Yesterday I was greatly amazed when I came from the market and found that you had made your bed, sir.

question: And Gaston, I was happier all day long. I felt I'd contributed something.
answer: Well, sir, if you should do it again, which I hope you won't, please remember the order. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet.

question: Ah, there's something poetic about the simple processes of labor. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet... it should be set to music!
answer: May I add, sir, that it was with great amazement that I found a copy of Karl Marx's Capital on your night table. That is a socialistic volume which I refuse to so much as dust, sir. I view with alarm, sir, the influence over you of this Bolshevik lady.

question: I can't follow you, Gaston, isn't it about time that you realized the unfairness of your position? You being my servant? Wouldn't you like to stand on an equal footing with me?
answer: No, sir.

question: Isn't there any revolt in you? Sometimes when I order you around don't you feel like kicking me in the pants?
answer: No, sir.

question: Oh, you're a reactionary! Don't you look forward to the day when you can come in here and stand square on your two feet and say, "Hey, you, d'Algout! from now on it's going to be share and share alike"?
answer: Emphatically not, sir. The prospect terrifies me. Now, don't misunderstand me, sir, I don't resent your not paying me for the past two months, but the thought that I should split my bank account with you... that you should take half of my life's savings... that is really too much for me.

question: Go to bed, little father, go to bed.
answer: I don't look too foolish?

question: Foolish? If this dress were to walk down the boulevard all by itself I would follow it from one end of Paris to the other, and when I caught up with it I would say, "Just a moment, you charming little dress, I want you to meet Ninotchka... you two were meant for each other." Ninotchka feels more comfortable. You remember this room?
answer: I've never been here before. I wonder whom you're thinking of. Oh, I know, a girl with a map, figuring out each step, worrying about north and south. Today... now this might shock you... I went up to a taxi and said "Eight Rue du Bois"... and here I am.

question: You see? Life can be so simple.
answer: For twelve francs, seventy-five.

question: Twelve seventy-five from the Clarence? The son-of-a-gun made a detour!... But he got you here.
answer: It's nine o'clock.

question: That's when one half of Paris says to the other half, "What are your plans for this evening, madame?"
answer: Well, first I should like to take off my hat and jacket. Then could we have some music?

question: A wonderful idea! Radio or records?
answer: Not radio. Let's have music that's just for ourselves.

question: I'll play it softly because I have things to tell you about which I can't shout. Well, my darling... I... we... You see I couldn't shout that.
answer: Leon, you know the jokes you told me a few days ago? I wake up in the middle of the night and laugh at them. Now, Leon that's wrong. I know they're not funny, they're silly. They're stupid. And still... I laugh... and when I look at Buljanoff and Iranoff and Kopalski I know they are scoundrels and I should hate them -- then I realize who made them like that, and instead of sending my report to Moscow I tear it up and go down and buy a ridiculous hat... and if this keeps on... am I too talkative?

question: No... go on.
answer: Leon, I want to tell you something which I thought I never would say, which I thought nobody ever should say, because I thought it didn't exist... and, Leon... I can't say it...

question: What a gesture for a sergeant.
answer: Leon, I would like to ask you something.

question: Anything, Ninotchka.
answer: If you don't want to answer, you needn't. But if you do, you must tell me the truth.

question: I promise... I swear.
answer: Did you make any change in this room?

question: I don't think so.
answer: When I was here before I noticed a photograph of a woman on the desk in a wide silver frame. I thought what a waste of silver. That's all that interested me then. Now I would like to know... what happened to the woman? The Duchess. She is very attractive. She has great elegance. She's what you call a woman of the world, isn't she?

question: Ninotchka, I love you.
answer: I suppose she is very entertaining... It must be lots of fun to be with her, so witty, so glamorous...

question: Ninotchka, you're jealous.
answer: Leon, don't ever ask me for a picture of myself... I couldn't bear the thought of being shut up in a drawer... I couldn't breathe, I couldn't stand it.

question: Good evening, Your Highness.
answer: Good evening, Louis. You seem to be very crowded tonight. Can you manage a table near the floor?

question: Certainly, Your Highness, this way please... Count d'Algout made the reservation this afternoon.
answer: Count d'Algout...

question: It is only a small table but it will be no trouble to put in some extra chairs.
answer: No, that's another party. No, no! This is glory! At last I'm going to have a look at that female Bolshevik. Can you give us another table?

question: Only one in the rear, I'm afraid.
answer: That's perfect! Isn't it divine? Now, we must be very discreet. If she sucks her soup and drinks out of her finger bowl, I don't want anyone to laugh. We must not embarrass little Leon. He is going through enough for my sake. We mustn't add insult to injury

question: Is this satisfactory?
answer: Thank you, Louis.

question: Possibly later. We'll just start with champagne.
answer: I'm only afraid that the doorman may spoil our fun. If only he lets her in!

question: Your Highness...
answer: Yes, General Savitzky?

question: I want you to know all the White Russian exiles in Paris are keeping their fingers crossed about the jewels. They are very interested in the case. Swana suspects her countrymen.
answer: Are they indeed? Thank you.

question: They hope the settlement will bring you a fortune.
answer: General, please... if you hear any rumors that I am a charitable person, will you please kill them at their source? Shall we dance, General Savitzky?

question: Is it dry? Is that right or do you prefer it sweet?
answer: I wouldn't know. The closest I ever came to champagne was in a newsreel. The wife of some president was throwing it at a battleship.

question: It's always good luck to launch something with champagne; a battleship... or an evening.
answer: It's funny to look back. I was brought up on goat's milk, I had a ration of vodka in the army, and now champagne.

question: From goats to grapes. That's drinking in the right direction.
answer: Ugh... um... oh... It's good. From what I read I thought champagne was a strong drink. It's very delicate. Do people ever get drunk on this?

question: Thank you.
answer: Is this your new dress suit?

question: Yes, Swana.
answer: Didn't I tell you Benson and Benson were the tailors for you?

question: Yes, Swana, you did.
answer: It's a dream of beauty. He never takes my word for anything, but I was right, wasn't I?

question: Yes, Swana.
answer: Am I interrupting?

question: Not at all. Your Highness, may I present Madame Yakushova?
answer: How do you do?

question: I'm going, Leon... but before I leave I must compliment you on your gown, Madame Yakushova. Is that what they're wearing in Moscow this year?
answer: No, last year, madame.

question: Isn't it amazing! One gets a wrong impression of the new Russia. It must be charming. I'm glad conditions are so improved. I assume this is what the factory workers wear at their dances?
answer: Exactly. You see, it would have been embarrassing for people of my sort to wear low-cut gowns in the old Russia. The lashes of the Cossacks across our backs were not very becoming, and you know how vain women are.

question: Good night, Swana.
answer: Now I think I need a glass of champagne. Quickly, please... tell me one of your funny stories.

question: A funny story?
answer: You never finished the one about the two Scotchmen with the names.

question: Well, there were two Scotchmen. One was named McIntosh and one was named McGillicuddy. They met on the street.
answer: Go on.

question: No, darling. I'll tell you another story, a much better one. The only thing that will be over on Thursday is the lawsuit. There will be no Thursday for us. Not next week or any week. We won't let it happen. I'll tear it out of the calendar. Is that a good story?
answer: Wonderful -- if one could believe it.

question: You must, darling.
answer: To the loveliest story I ever heard. Shall we dance? Oo! Darling! Something is the matter.

question: You just made that trip from goats to grapes a little too fast.
answer: Oh, everything is so wonderful! It's getting farther and farther away!

question: What, darling?
answer: Thursday.

question: Yes. Don't worry. Everything will be all right.
answer: Comrades! Comrades!

question: Darling, darling... please!
answer: I must talk to my brothers!

question: Shhh! Shhh!
answer: Don't shush me. I am People! I want to make a speech. I want to overthrow the Duchess!

question: But, darling, you can't do that.
answer: Comrades! Good people of France!

question: Now, Ninotchka... please!
answer: They are all Duchesses here... thousands of Duchesses... and I am going to tell them.

question: Quite right... yes, yes, yes, but first you're going in that door and you're going to take a little spirits of ammonia and lie down.
answer: No speech?

question: No speech.
answer: I love you, my little Leonitchka!

question: And I adore you, Ninotchua. Give me a double brandy.
answer: I'm very sorry, Count d'Algout, it is most embarrassing, but the lady you brought with you tonight is spreading communistic propaganda in the powder room.

question: Give me another double brandy.
answer: That kind of propaganda is bad anywhere, but inciting the attendants of a powder room to go on strike.... Well, if she succeeds the consequences will be disastrous.

question: What can I do about it?
answer: She has been asked to leave the powder room but without success. We would appreciate if you would see to it yourself.

question: You want me to go in there?
answer: I'm sorry, sir, but I must insist.

question: Make it a triple brandy. As we All right... you can tell the Duchess... you can tell everybody... they know anyhow... it doesn't make any difference... now get out!
answer: Don't tell them where we're going, sweetheart.

question: No. Nobody will find us.
answer: Are we going to build our little house?

question: Yes... a little white house.
answer: Not white, darling.

question: All right, we'll make it red.
answer: No, don't let's have it any color... no color... just a house house... let's form our own party.

question: Right
answer: And we won't stretch up our arms...

question: No! No!
answer: ...and we won't clench our fist...

question: No! No!
answer: Our salute will be a kiss.

question: Yes... a kiss... salute!
answer: I am so happy. No one can be so happy without being punished. I will be punished and I should be punished. I want to confess, darling.

question: I know... it's the Russian soul.
answer: Everyone wants to confess and if they don't confess they make them confess. I am a traitor. When I kissed you I betrayed the Russian ideal. Leon, I should be stood up against the wall.

question: Would that make you any happier?
answer: Much happier.

question: All right.
answer: I have paid the penalty. Now let's have some music.

question: Let's turn on the radio.
answer: Radio! What is radio?

question: It's a little box that you buy on the installment plan and before you tune it in they tell you they have a new model.
answer: Oh yes, yes. It has a little knob that turns... a little knob... it must be somewhere around here... yes... here... I see... Here it is!

question: What shall we get? The news!
answer: No, no news. We don't want to know what's happening in the world. We want to be left alone, don't we?

question: Yes, sweetheart... all by ourselves.
answer: Well, then we turn twice to the right and stop at seven... It's dead.

question: Well, it has to warm up... you have to give it a chance... just like people... like you and me... first you wanted to fight me and now we belong to the same party... salute!
answer: Now twice to the left and stop at seventeen. No music.

question: No, no music.
answer: There it is... Thursday... you can't rip it out of the week....

question: But I can throw it out of the window.
answer: It wouldn't be fair to the man in the street. There they are... they are terrible things, those jewels....

question: ...but big.
answer: ...they are the tears of Old Russia... see that stone?

question: Who cried that one?
answer: Czar Peter gave it to his wife, Catherine the Great. For it he sold ten thousand serfs in the market.

question: Now, darling, don't get impatient, wait until we are married. You know that worthless butler of mine... that reactionary? Some day when I come home to you I may say, "Darling, I drove Gaston to the market and look what I got from him!"
answer: First ten thousand serfs... now just Gaston. It is very encouraging.

question: Come, sweetheart. Let me put it on you. You will teach these jewels. For the first time they will learn how they can look.
answer: They belong to the people.

question: I give them back to the people... I make you Ninotchka the Great... Duchess of the People!... Grand Duchess of the People!
answer: Is this the wish of the masses?

question: It is their wish.
answer: Thank you, Leon... thank you, masses. Can I make a speech now?

question: Please.
answer: Comrades! People of the world! The revolution is on the march... I know... wars will wash over us... bombs will fall... all civilization will crumble... but not yet, please... wait, wait... what's the hurry? Let us be happy... give us our moment.... We are happy, aren't we, Leon?

question: Yes, sweetheart.
answer: So happy and so tired. Smile, little father, smile.

question: So happy and so tired. Smile, little father, smile.
answer: Good morning.

question: What?
answer: It is tomorrow morning... tomorrow noon, to be exact. I hope you will forgive me. I know it's extremely cruel to waken anyone at such an hour. Don't you recognize me? I am the Duchess Swana. I know how you feel, my dear. The morning after always does look grim if you happen to be wearing last night's dress. Don't be embarrassed by my presence, though. You couldn't have found anybody more sympathetic to your condition. I remember once in Petrograd when I felt exactly as you do. I had to bow from a balcony to the crowd. My dear, the masses have no understanding of the feelings of a lady before noon. Don't you find that true?

question: I think we can cut your visit short. Leon is not here.
answer: Of course not, my dear! I didn't come here with any such suspicion. How ridiculous! Nor did I come here to pick up his hat. How stale last night's gaiety looks! It has the taste of a dead cigarette.

question: If you were encouraged to come here by our meeting last night I am afraid you misunderstood my attitude.
answer: Don't worry, you were quite rude enough. Do you mind if I let in a little fresh air and sunshine? I'm sure it will make you feel better and I want you to be at your very best. In full possession of your faculties, at least.

question: Please come to the point. What is it you want?
answer: I just dropped in to have a little heart-to-heart talk with you.

question: We have nothing to discuss.
answer: Now there you are completely wrong. If we sit down for a little chat, I'm sure we won't run out of conversation and what's more it won't be dull.

question: Madame, what is it you people always say, regardless of what you mean... "I am delighted to have you here"? I have not reached that stage of civilization.
answer: That's all right... I grow on people.

question: I must ask you to leave.
answer: Leave? That's exactly what I came here to ask you to do. Leave! I don't mean this hotel and I don't mean Paris... I mean France. There's a plane for Moscow at five-forty.

question: Madame, if you...
answer: Don't worry. I have already made reservations. It's perfect flying weather. They assure me there's a fine tail wind which will sweep you back to Moscow in no time.

question: If this is meant to be a joke it is not funny. Or do you still think you're issuing orders from your palace in Petrograd?
answer: My palace in Petrograd... yes, you took that away from me. You took away my czar, my country, my people, everything I had... but nothing more -- I warn you.

question: People cannot be taken away, madame, neither a hundred and sixty million nor one. Not if you have their love. You hadn't. That's why you're not in Russia any longer, and that's why you came here this morning.
answer: Very interesting, my dear, but couldn't you write all that from Moscow? A dissertation on love on Soviet stationery -- would be an amusing paradox.

question: It is not enough to be witty, madame. People grow tired of being entertained. You made that mistake before. Problems were never solved by bowing from a balcony.
answer: My dear, you don't know how impressive I could be. Did you ever see me in my regalia with my diadem and all my jewels? You can't deny we gave the people their money's worth -- almost -- eight tumbling Romanoffs -- eight!

question: I must insist that you leave.
answer: Not before you agree to use those reservations to Moscow.

question: In that case I can only say good-by. lyse 2763.
answer: I wouldn't waken Leon. After last night I would say not before three o'clock at the earliest.

question: I told you to go, madame.
answer: Believe me, Leon can't help you. He doesn't know anything about the jewels... I give you my word... I swear it.

question: Where are they?
answer: You were very careless with our precious jewels, my dear. They're too expensive a toy for two children to play with.

question: Where are they?
answer: Don't worry. Fortunately last night a very trustworthy friend kept his eyes open. Perhaps he overstepped his function as a waiter but he fulfilled his duty as a Russian. I just put this on for sentiment. The rest are absolutely safe. I assure you. But if you feel like notifying the police...

question: You leave me no choice.
answer: Won't it be rather embarrassing for a Soviet Envoy to disclose the circumstances under which she lost them?

question: I will have to face the consequences, but so will you. Don't forget they will ask how you got them.
answer: That's very simple to answer. They were given to me by my mother. They were given to her by her mother, in fact they're mine, you cannot steal what belongs to you!

question: They always belonged to the Russian people. They were paid for with their sweat, their blood, their lives and you will give them back!
answer: I told you we had plenty to talk about. Shall we sit down? Now, let's free ourselves from emotionalism and try to solve the problem in a practical way. Our situation has changed considerably. Before I had only a claim to the jewels. Now I have the jewels.

question: In other words moral ideas have no weight with you... all right, then let's deal with legal facts. You know that France has recognized the Soviet.
answer: Unfortunately.

question: Under Soviet law the jewels belong to the State. France is going to uphold that ownership.
answer: My lawyer agrees with you. He says France will uphold it in every court, but I will drag you through every court, don't forget that. And when I say it will take two years I am, as always, conservative.

question: Won't those two years in court be expensive for you? I know that money was no object as long as you could squeeze it from the pockets of the people, but now...
answer: I may run out of money, but you have already run out of bread. Two years is a long time for your comrades to wait.

question: I see. You have calculated in terms of hunger.
answer: No, I just wanted to be absolutely impartial. Both of us are faced with two rather uncomfortable years. We can condense these two years to two minutes if you want to accept my proposition. Ninotchka now realizes what she is after.

question: Go on.
answer: I am willing to hand over the jewels and sign the necessary papers if you take that five-forty plane to Moscow.

question: That's not the way to win him back... not Leon.
answer: I think I know Leon quite as well as you... possibly a little better. Leave that worry to me. Five-forty leaves you time enough to close the deal with Monsieur Mercier, but naturally you'll be too busy for any farewells. I'll see to it that everything is done in the most expeditious manner and I will also see you to the airport. That's my proposition, Comrade Yakushova.

question: Yes... Oh hello... Good morning, Leon... ... no, you didn't waken me... I am fine, thank you.... Yes, it was... marvelous.... What?... for luncheon? I'm afraid I can't. I am going to be very busy... well, I have a lot of things to attend to today.... What?... Well to tell you the truth I am a little tired and I would like to rest... you may be right... perhaps it is the champagne.... For dinner?... Of course... seven o'clock here?... seven o'clock is all right.... Where?... That will be lovely.... Yes... Come in. Yes?... Just a moment... You can leave it here. She smiles sadly and goes to the telephone, which is on the console in the anteroom. Operator, will you switch the call please?... Hello?... Darling, your present just arrived.... It's very silly and very wonderful... thank you... No, I won't forget... seven o'clock.... Good-by, my darling.... What?... Oh... salute! I am sorry to have kept you waiting, madame.
answer: Good afternoon, Jacqueline.

question: Good afternoon, Jacqueline.
answer: Good afternoon, Your Highness. Madame, I...

question: You didn't find my glove. All right, you're forgiven.
answer: Thank you, Your Highness. Count d'Algout is waiting. He's been here some time.

question: Leon, darling, how nice! Have you ordered tea or a cocktail?
answer: No thanks, Swana.

question: Did I act stupidly last night? Should I apologize?
answer: I'm the one who should apologize. I should have talked to you before.

question: Is this, by any chance, going to be a confession?
answer: Yes.

question: Oh, no, my little Volga boatman. Have you forgotten our First Commandment
answer: This time, Swana -- just this once -- I must ask you to listen.

question: All right, I'll listen.
answer: I know you hate the obvious but do you mind if, at this moment, I'm not in the least subtle?

question: Brutal frankness, if you insist.
answer: There are a hundred ways to approach it, but I feel it can best be said in one simple phrase. I'm in love, Swana.

question: And I thought it was something serious! How could you frighten me so?
answer: It must be serious, Swana. Not long ago I'd have considered such a statement rather juvenile and rather middle class. Now I can say it without stammering, without a blush. I'm in love, Swana.

question: Say it over and over again, Leon. Words are a wonderful safety valve, and that's what you need -- because you know it's impossible, don't you?
answer: I have to be simple again, Swana, and you may find it shockingly banal. I've thought it over and I'm willing to take all the consequences, even if it means a complete readjustment of my way of living.

question: Leon! This has the ugly sound of regeneration.
answer: I'm afraid that's what it is.

question: The same old trouble, Leon. You're always late. Whether you're taking me to the Opera or calling for me at a beauty shop, you're never on time. And now, when it's a question of your reform -- late again. By about five minutes.
answer: What is this, Swana?

question: Knowing the efficiency of the French Air Service I think I can guarantee that Madame Yakushova has already taken off for Moscow.
answer: Has done what?

question: She's gone, Leon.
answer: Do you expect me to believe that?

question: Well, everything is in order. I hope you will enjoy your trip to Russia, madame. Certainly not, madame. That's only capitalistic propaganda. We change the towel every week. Yes, please? Yes... Comrade Cazabine? No, I'm sorry... he hasn't been with us for six months. He was called back to Russia and was investigated. You can get further details from his widow.
answer: Pardon me, I am very interested in what you just said -- you mean when an envoy goes back to Russia -- if they don't like what he has done they put him out of the way?

question: Not always... look at me... I've been back twice.
answer: Here's my passport.... Please give me a visa. I have to leave for Russia immediately.

question: Count Leon d'Algout... a count!... a nobleman!
answer: Don't hold that against me... please!

question: Why should an aristocrat want to go to Russia?
answer: Business.

question: What business?
answer: Private.

question: There is no privacy in Russia. This whole thing seems very suspicious. What's the real reason? If you ever want to get into Russia, take my advice... confess!
answer: Confess what?

question: Are you sympathetic to the former Czaristic government -- the White Russians?
answer: On the contrary -- I don't want to have anything to do with them.

question: You believe in our cause?
answer: Oh... I think it's great! Everyone works -- everyone contributes -- that's what I want to do -- work! I make my own bed -- you can call up my butler! I don't believe in the right of the individual. I like the Bolshevik ideal -- everyone being the same. You just like me -- me just like you -- I use your comb -- you use my toothbrush -- oh, it's a great life.... Please... give me that visa!

question: Oh... I think it's great! Everyone works -- everyone contributes -- that's what I want to do -- work! I make my own bed -- you can call up my butler! I don't believe in the right of the individual. I like the Bolshevik ideal -- everyone being the same. You just like me -- me just like you -- I use your comb -- you use my toothbrush -- oh, it's a great life.... Please... give me that visa!
answer: Hello, Leon darling!

question: Hello.
answer: After our talk last night I took it for granted that you would drop in here this morning. Knowing how difficult it is to get into Soviet Russia, I thought I might be of some assistance to you. May I introduce myself? I am the Duchess Swana of Russia... another Russia.

question: Now, please, Swana.
answer: Count d'Algout was for several years my personal representative and if it is necessary to sign any affidavit for him I'll be delighted.

question: That does it, Swana. Now you mustn't miss your appointment with your hair-dresser.
answer: Just in case they don't give you your visa to Russia I want you to know that I have signed a contract for my memoirs and rented a lovely little chteau in the Touraine, and if you feel the need of a change...

question: Thank you, Swana. You are very gracious. She must have her little joke. You're not going to take that seriously.
answer: The Grand Duchess Swana... active in the White Russian movement?

question: Believe me, I have no connection with her any longer... I swear I haven't!
answer: But you had!

question: Listen, I want to be absolutely frank with you. I have no business in Moscow.
answer: I think so too.

question: I want to see a friend of mine... a very dear friend.... It's a personal matter which has nothing to do with politics or social philosophies.... It's a girl.
answer: So it's love which drags you to Moscow.

question: Yes!
answer: No visa.

question: I must get into that country of yours!
answer: Oh no. No visa.

question: That's impossible! Nobody has the right.... You can't do that!... If you don't give me that visa...
answer: You're going to force us... huh?

question: Now look here... you advertise all over the world that you want people to go into your country and when someone tries to get in, you keep him out!
answer: Why should I take a chance?

question: On what?
answer: How do I know you don't want to blow up a factory?

question: What for... why?
answer: Or a tunnel or a bridge...

question: Suspicions... nothing but suspicions!... That's the trouble with you! If you don't let me in I'll stand in front of this office of yours and warn people to keep away from Russia!... I'll picket your whole country.... I'll boycott you, that's what I'm going to do!... No more vodka... no more caviar... no more Tchaikovsky... no more borscht.... Wait a minute, I know something better than that...
answer: What?

question: And you can tell the Kremlin that's just the beginning!
answer: No visa.

question: Good evening, Anna.
answer: Good evening, Ninotchka.

question: Aren't you late?
answer: No, the opera starts an hour later tonight on account of the parade.

question: Didn't you march?
answer: They didn't let me. I am in disgrace. Last week at the performance of Carmen I played a sour note. The conductor got so excited he yelled, "There's sabotage in the string section!"

question: Too bad... you missed an inspiring day, Anna.
answer: I know... my heart is sad... but my feet are happy. When all the tanks and guns were roaring over the Red Square I sat here all by myself and played a Beethoven sonata. Not bad at all. Are you expecting someone?

question: A few friends... just a little dinner party.
answer: What are you serving?

question: An omelet.
answer: An omelet! Aren't you living a little above your ration?

question: Well, I've saved up two eggs and each of my friends is bringing his own so we'll manage.
answer: It just goes to prove the theory of our State. If you stand alone it means a boiled egg but if you're true to the collective spirit and stick together you've got an omelet. That reminds me... have you heard the latest they're telling about the Kremlin? I'll tell you later. That Gurganov, you never know whether he's on his way to the washroom or the Secret Police.

question: You should be more careful, Anna.
answer: And you too, Ninotchka.

question: About what?
answer: Ever since you have been back from Paris...

question: I haven't talked to anyone about Paris. I haven't said a word.
answer: That's just it. It makes people feel queer. I dont' want you to get in any trouble.

question: I have nothing to hide.
answer: You should. I'll show you. When I passed through the laundry yard today I saw all the women huddled around this so I brought it up here. Things like this create a bad feeling. First they didn't know whose it was. Then they saw the Paris label and did it start a commotion! Some said it's what we all ought to wear and others said it's like hanging foreign ideas on our clothesline. It undermines our whole cause.

question: I see.
answer: You know how it is today... all you have to do is wear a pair of silk stockings and they suspect you of counter-revolution.

question: Thank you, Anna. I'll dry it up here when I wash it next. I should hate to see our country endangered by my underwear.
answer: Ninotchka, you know I am your friend, you can trust me.... Did you bring back anything else?

question: No, I left everything in Paris. I just happened to be wearing this.
answer: Tell me... what else did you have?

question: Well, a hat...
answer: What was it like?

question: It was very silly.... I would be ashamed to wear it here.
answer: As beautiful as that? What else? Come, tell me.

question: An evening gown.
answer: Evening gown?

question: A dress you wear in the evening.
answer: What do you wear in the morning?

question: When you get up you put on a negligee, and then you change to a morning frock.
answer: You mean to tell me you wear a different dress for different times of the day?

question: Yes.
answer: Now, Ninotchka, you're exaggerating.

question: No, my dear, it is true. That's how they live in the other world. Here we dress to have our bodies covered... to keep warm....
answer: And there?

question: Well, sometimes they're not completely covered but... they don't freeze.
answer: They must have wonderful materials to make a thing like this so soft... something you don't even see.

question: You feel it, though.
answer: Ninotchka, I wouldn't bring this up if we weren't such good friends.

question: What is it, Anna?
answer: You know I told you that Pavlov and I are going to get married when he comes back from the maneuvers. Would it be asking too much...

question: You want this?
answer: Just for the honeymoon.

question: You can have it for good. It is my wedding present.
answer: Ninotchka! Ninotchka! Am I going to play that cadenza tonight!

question: Good morning, Comrade.
answer: Good morning, Comrade Commissar. Here is my report on the materials available for trading in the next four months.

question: Does this include the products of the Far Eastern provinces?
answer: Yes, it does.

question: You mean you have finished the whole investigation?
answer: Yes.

question: That's marvelous.... You must have worked day and night.... Don't you ever sleep?
answer: I need very little sleep. We must be extremely careful what goods we take in exchange. I have already started a survey of our most urgent needs.

question: Well, Comrade, I am afraid you will have to turn over that work to someone else.
answer: May I ask why?

question: Please... sit down. Cigarette?
answer: Thank you.

question: Well, Comrade, have you heard from your friends Kopalski, Buljanoff, and Iranoff?
answer: No.

question: I haven't either, but I've heard about them. You must realize it was only on the strength of your Paris report that I sent them to Constantinople; without that I never would have trusted them on a mission as important as the fur deal.
answer: May I ask what has happened?

question: As soon as our representatives go to a foreign country they seem to lose all sense of balance. If I told you what's going on in Constantinople right now you wouldn't believe it. Those three have been sitting there for six weeks and haven't sold a piece of fur. This anonymous report was sent me. They are dragging the good name of our country through every caf and night club. Here... "How can the Bolshevik cause gain respect among the Moslems if your three representatives, Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski, get so drunk that they throw a carpet out of their hotel window and complain to the management that it didn't fly?"
answer: Oh, they shouldn't do such things. Are you sure this report is correct?

question: It gives details which couldn't be invented. Naturally I want to verify it and that's why I need you.
answer: You want me to go to Constantinople?

question: Yes... leaving immediately.
answer: I appreciate the confidence you show in me, but I must ask you to entrust someone else with this mission. I should hate to interrupt my present work. I am positive that my survey is more important than finding out whether three of our comrades have been drinking some extra glasses of champagne.

question: That is for me to decide, Comrade Yakushova.
answer: I am sorry, I don't want to overstep my position -- but please... don't send me.

question: I don't understand.
answer: How can I make myself clear... It is difficult to express but I'd rather not go to foreign countries any more. Please, Comrade... let me stay here... let me finish my work... I am in the rhythm of it now... I don't want to go away. I don't want to be sent into that foreign atmosphere again. It throws one out of gear.... Let me finish my work... I have concentrated everything in it... Please... don't make me go.

question: Please don't waste my time, Comrade. Do your duty. Good-by.
answer: I will do my best.

question: No, that's bad management.
answer: Is it possible to bring you back to reality for a moment? I must have a complete report of your negotiations and a detailed expense account.

question: Don't ask for it, Ninotchka. There is a Turkish proverb which says, "If something smells bad, why put your nose in it?"
answer: And there is a Russian saying

question: With our cream situation what it is, it is Russia which should apologize to the cats.
answer: Friends... friends, Buljanoff, Iranoff...

question: All you have to do is say "open sesame."
answer: I don't know how I can get you out of it this time. How will it end? What will happen to you?

question: Shall we tell her? Ninotchka, I hope you'll be our guest.
answer: Guest?
